line.tr: ... for sure my wish may be fulfilled, may I have a pure way of living [lit. living of life] consisting of wisdom by (this three-fold de)ed! Avoiding (suffering) [and] happiness (in) the sharing ...
... (May I avoid the) danger (of the passions), [and] may I always become without anger through this deed! Which [= the Brāhmaṇavarga] makes rain jewels of meanings like the cintāmaṇi gem,

through this excellent writing (of the excellent Brāhmaṇavarga, superior to everything), may I make manifest the noble eightfold path that goes to the city of Nirvāṇa! May [the beings] (of the five births) reach the happiness consisting in the extinction of all sufferings

(through the wish coming from me)! 40. I have written with a great wish the excellent (U)dānavarga (provided with meaning [and] [literary] form, which chases away) the diseases of the passions, the good jewel of the Law, the excellent one, that has been bought by the dear lives of the omniscents as numerous as the grains of sand of the Ganges. May the darkness of ignorance of [the beings] of the five births disappear through this deed! 41. (Having heard the great baskets [i.e., the canonical writings]) that exist through wonder,

Das mit den lieben Leben der dem Sand in der Gaṅgā gleichenden Alleswissenden erkaufte vorzügliche Gesetzesjuwel, das gute, die Kleśa-Krankheiten vertreibende, den herrlichen Udāna[varga], habe ich (sinn- [und] buchstabengetreu [wtl. mit dem Sinn [und] dem Buchstaben an seiner Stelle]) geschrieben in dem großen Wunsche: Möge die Finsternis der Unwissenheit den fünfgeburtenwesen durch diese Tat vergehen!

The excellent law-jewel, bought with the dear lives of the Omniscients, alike to the sand in the Gaṅgā, the good one, expelling the kleśa-diseases, the magnificent Udāna[varga] I have written, (faithful in meaning and letter [lit. with the meaning [and] the letter in its place]), greatly wishing: may, through this deed, the darkness of ignorance disappear for the beings of the five incarnations!
Möge die Finsternis der Unwissenheit den Fünfgeburtenwesen durch diese Tat vergehen!
Because of this deed, may the darkness of ignorance pass for the beings of the five incarnations!

since for (each) single śloka you [the Buddha] have given by thousands [your] heads to be cut off, [and] to flay your skin from the body, your (energy) did (not) wane to make flow [your] blood, [and your] m(arrow).

(O lord, by selling yourself) blood overflowed out from (e)ighty thousand pores. 42. My spirit arose in order to proclaim the great striving of the good king of Riṣis. Through a speech in Kuchean manner, ...
Es erhob sich in mir der Gedanke, die große Anstrengung des guten Königs der Ṛṣis zu verkünden.
The thought arose in me to proclaim the great effort of the good king of the Ṛṣis.
I myself am (without capac)ity, nevertheless I have taken away this firmness from life [and] body, and I (pro)claim precisley this wish: May I become an omniscient for sure (through) this deed! 43.
Und nur diesen Wunsch verkünde ich: "Möchte ich ganz bestimmt ein Allerkenner werden (durch) diese Tat!"
And this [one] wish only I proclaim: "May I most certainly become an all-perceiving one due to this deed!"

(For the sake of the Law) may I abandon [as lightly] as (grass) my head [and] this (living)! May I become unconcerned [and] may I not care about life, (sen)ses, [and] (bo)dies! May I obtain the support of aware(ness)!
Und möchte ich unbekümmert sein [und] auf Leben, Sinne [und] Körper nicht Rücksicht nehmen.
And may I be unconcerned [and] not consider life, the senses [and] the body.

May (the companion of firmness not lea)ve (me)! With the wish for omniscience I will myself go the way of the (Law) without stop. (44.) May my heart turn into a diamond in order to endure (my own suff)erings!

comments.comment: only edited lines a4-a5 of the recto side. Part of the text can be restored with the help of = S 7 a 5-b 2. It belongs to the short version of the Udānastotra where the text proper ends with stanza no. 40.

The original has been lost since at least the 1980ies, and since it did not make it into the numbering of the series PK AS even in the 1950ies, it is likely that it was already lost by that time. However, Lévi still used it for his 1933 book.
According to the description of Lévi preserved in his first draft of the 1933 book, the leaf lacks the left part including the string hole.
Note the preservation of word-final -ä of sakwä, which is metrically warranted.

The text is partly restored with the help of b 2, although there we have the finite preterite form paiykāmai of the verb pikā - instead of an abstract. Accordingly, the pāda 40b had no finite verb, which stands in the following pāda.

The missing eleven syllables of pāda 43a probably contained a sentence referring to the composition of the praise of the Udānavarga as being first told by the Buddha in contrast to the actual praise in the Kuchean language.

Lévi had the reading klāwäṣṣi, but such an optative/imperfect forms does not make sense in this passage; the correct form, the infinitive klāwässi has actually been read by Lévi in his first draft. Note that in the glossary on p. 123 Lévi also analyzes the form correctly an infinitive (while still giving the wrong reading with ṣṣi).
Lévi has the wrong form kektseñi in the edited text, but the correct form kektseñän in note 6.

comments.comment: Likely komnak instead of **komtak. komnak would make more morphonological sense: *kaunak to komnak is the same kind of change as in larauñe to laromñe (cf. also komne in PK DA M 507.27 b3). komtak on the other hand is completely intransparent.

pakaccāṃ is a difficult word. considers it to be a loan from Sanskrit *upagacchana, an equivalent of upanāyikā-, denoting the 'entering', i.e. beginning, of vassa. also connects this word to vassa and alleges that it originates from Sanskrit *bhakta-chedana-, an equivalent of bhakta-chinnaka 'fasting'. argues that pakaccāṃ did not originally denote vassa itself, but a particular kind of action a dānapati performs, namely promising to supply the monastery for 3-4 months, coinciding with vassa. She shows that there were two periods of pakaccāṃ, one in the later third of the fourth month and one in the middle of the last month. The old turkic equivalent is b(a)kcan, cf. , the Sogdian pkc'n, cf. .
The Tsañi is a kind of monastery functionary, cf. the 'Findings'-section.
It looks like the scribe first wrote 'kñu', but then corrected the akṣara.

comments.comment: *aṣtamikka certainly is derived from Sanskrit aṣtamī, which seems to be the equivalent of oktaśke. Thus the aṣtamikka-women might fulfill some particular function within the celebration of this day; though they also interact with the saṃgha on days other than oktaśke, cf. PK DA M 507.35 a15.

This is a turkish proper name, bäg meaning 'lord' and cor being the title of an official, reflected in chinese as 啜 (). It is interesting to note that the voiced 'b' is spelled as 'mp' in this document, while in A 382 a3 the same word is spelled as bhek.

comments.comment: Olīśkantsa is a perlative plural. Place names that are pluralia tantum are also found in other Indo-European languages, like Greek Ἀθῆναι or Latin Cannae. olīśkantsa needs to be a plural (for the inflection of forms in -śke/-ṣke, see ). The function of the perlative is the denotation of the purpose of the coins, i.e. 'for Olīśka', cf. (pu)tatāsentse warwantsaisa cokiś ṣalywe ṣaṅk.

comments.comment: peres is an obscure hapax legomenon. Here, I interpreted it as a genitive plural form of *pere (like kapyāres), which occurs in akwam-pere 'sprout and stalk'. comments.comment: Ching segments this as wässintse ṣeṃ and considers this to be a loan word from chinese 衫 or 扇. However, in the case of 衫 one would expect ṣem, not ṣeṃ, and 扇 means 'leaf of a door' or 'fan', thus it would not be a good fit semantically. I consider this form a substantivization of an adjective *wässintseṣṣe, a -ṣṣe form of wässintse, itself a genitive hypostasis, meaning 'clothing, garments', which is attested in Ot 12 a8. The form might also occur in .
This is probably the same word as in olākwāṃṣe in PK DA M 507.24. considers it to be the equivalent of chinese 乌骆馆, 馆 being a 'post station', which among other things collected taxes.

This is a very interesting construction. We have keś tättār, a nominalization of the phrase keś tā- 'judge, consider, weigh'. Then meñ seems to be the direct object of keś tättār, so 'the consideration of the month'. This in turn is adjectivized: 'pertaining to the consideration of the month' or more simply: 'pertaining to the month'. Thus we have: 'The coins pertaining to the month', i.e. the monthly amount.
The scribe seems to have written 'ṅwā' first and shoddily added 'k' in afterwards.

line.tr: The 6th month. On the 8th day of the month, [I gave the wheat] as the food [of] saṃgha (to process?) outside: 5 pecks. (sb. has seen. This is his/her finger-measure.)
On the 11th day. [I gave] to Kercapiśke [the wheat] as the food [of saṃgha] (to process?) outside: 2 piculs, 5 pecks. Kercapiśke's finger-measure.
On the 21st day. (I gave to Kercapiśke) the wheat as the food of saṃgha (to process outside?): [2 piculs, 5 pecks] [Kercapiśke's] finger-measure.
The 7th month. On the 3rd day of the month ... /// /// I made (sb.) mill wheat : 10 piculs.
The 9th month. On the 5th day of the month, [I made (sb.) mill the wheat as the food of saṃgha]: five piculs. Therein, the fee (of milling) has been spent: 5 pecks.
The 10th month. On the 1st day, [I made (sb.) mill the wheat as the food of] saṃgha: 1 picul.
On the 13th day, I made (sb.) mill the wheat for pakacāṃ: 10 piculs.
On the 12th day of the 11th (month, I made sb. mill) wheat: [5 piculs].
On the 1st day of the 12th (month). I made (sb.) mill wheat: 2 piculs, 2 pecks.
On the 7th day of the month, (I made (sb.) mill) wheat for Rāp: ... [piculs], 4 pecks. |
On the 13th day, [I gave wheat] to Indrawarme to mill it: 1 picul, 5 pecks.

translation.line: Sixth month. On day of the month eight, I gave wheat for the consumption of the saṅgha outside: five pecks 5.
On day eleven, I gave wheat for the consumption of the saṅgha outside to Kercapiśke: two piculs 2 five pecks 5.
(This is) Kercapiśke's finger-measure.
On day twenty one, I gave wheat for the consumption of the saṅgha outside to Kercapiśke: two piculs 2, five pecks 5.
(This is) Kercapiśke's finger-measure.
Seventh month. On day of the month three, ... we ground wheat:
ten piculs 10.
Ninth month. On day of the month five, we ground wheat for the consumption of the saṅgha:
five piculs. For this a fee has been paid: five pecks 5.
Tenth month. On the day of the new moon, we ground wheat for the consumption of the saṅgha: one picul 1.
On day thirteen, (in the) tenth (month) we ground wheat for pakacāṃ: ten piculs 10.
Eleventh month. On day twelve, we ground wheat: five piculs 5.
Twelfth month. On the day of the full moon, we ground wheat: two piculs 2, two pecks 2.
On day of the month seven, wheat for rāp ... piculs, four pecks.
8 | On day of the month thirteen, I gave Indrawarme wheat for milling: a picul, five pecks.

comments.comment: The order of the date seems to be switched. Usually one would expect the month to come first, cf. PK DA M 507.2 a1: śkañce śak traiyne.

line.tr: In the 6th regnal year of the king Nāśmi, a year of monkey, on the 10th day of the 1st (month).
At that time, Amprätatewe the Stere gave the stūpa(s)' sarwante* to the Yotkolau monk Anandadewe.

He gave to him (in the following way: for every) 5 (coins), one (was out of the coins) of the saṃgha, 4 (were out of the coins) of the stūpa(s). (So) he gave to him 54 (coins). Therein, fourty-two were the [ones of the stūpa(s)] and twelve the ones of the saṃgha.
Anandadewe the Yotkolau's sign.
Jñā〈na〉sene has seen. This (is his) sign.
Jñānarakṣite has recognized. This (is his) sign.
Kercapiśke has seen. This (is his) finger-measure.

comments.comment: ¤: monogram, a ligature of ña and ā.
¤: monogram ñā.

他（这么）给他：（每）伍（文之中），一（文来自）僧物，肆（文来自）塔物。（于是）他（总共）给伍拾肆（文）。其中四十二（文）本来是塔物而十二（文）本来是僧物。
总管僧Anandadewe之签署。押
Jñānasene见到了，这（是）签署。押
Jñānarakṣite知道了，这（是）签署。押
Kercapiśke见到了，这（是）画指。押
In regnal year six of king Nāśmi in the year of the monkey, first month, on day of the month ten. At that time,
The Stere Amprätatewe gave sarwante pertaining to the stūpa to director Anandadewe.
He gave him five 5: One for the saṅgha, four for the stūpa. He gavre him fifty-
four 54. Therein, fourty two were for the stūpa, twelve for the saṅgha.
Director Anandadewe's signature ¤
Jñā(na)sene saw it. This (is his) signature ¤
Jñānarakṣite knew about it. This (is his) sign.
Kercapiśke saw it. This (is his) finger-measure.

The whole saṅgha living in Samantatir honors (you), the ācārya, the teacher.
aśari käṣṣiñiś samantatirne wsaṣeñca ysomo sāṅk yirṣalñe maskeṃntär

Lord, with your god-like wisdom, you have knowledge that the monastery Samantatir has been miserable and unfriendly for me for years and that through the effort of the Sthere Jñānasene and Āryatewe, the monastery has been reestablished alyuṣmaññe.

line.tr: To (our) teacher, the Aśari. The whole saṃgha living in Samatatir makes greetings (to you).
Oh lord! Because of (your) divine-like wisdom, you might already know how my Samantatir Monastery have been miserable and detestable for years.

Now, because of the effort of the Elders Āryatewe (and) Jñānasene, the monastery ... was re-established. The situation of the saṃgha is (now) proper, (and) we are attached to the good behavior (Skt. kuśalapakṣa-).

Oh lord! Concerning the four thousand (coins) as the previous debt owed by Puttisene with (our?) signature, the man from whom (the coins) were given did not keep contact with him. (Because) the man has been ... afar.
Now, he (Puttisene?) has undertaken the official labor services (to deliver) letters from Śiṅku(n).
In a manner deprived of (all) decency, he (= the creditor?) humiliates the saṃgha again (and) again.
Oh lord! (How) Puttisene had watched (over) this monastery, he (= the creditor?) seized (lit. 'robbed') in the same way.
So far is (our) account of the (accident).
What he has taken, he must give (back) to us. What we owe to him, we will give it to him.
If he gives back to me what he has carried off, we [will] give back to him what we owe.
Oh lord! What he has seized (lit. 'robbed'), he does not think (about its value). It is imposed on me as the *ṣorye-debt because of the violation (of contract?).
Because of this extreme situation, in the refuge in Śaṅke ('s place), he acts... unfriendly against us.

Now, the teacher (= the addressee) will please consider the way for us: how the monastery will not (lose?) estate again, (so that) the well-being of (my) saṃgha will not be spoilt. In the 1st regnal year, in the 12th month.
May the ācārya now think about an approach [lit. way] for us, so that the monastery will not (lose estate?)334 for a second time, and the proper situation of the community will not be terminated.
Wiryamitre the Saṅkästere wi
Wäryasene the Stere wry

Jñānasene the Stere ñā
Mokṣacandre the Praskāre mo
Āryatewe the [Stere] ā

translation.line: 致阿阇利尊师：住在Samantatir 的全体僧伽向您祝福致意。
尊者！由于您天神一般的洞察力，您可能已经知道我的 Samantatir 寺院这几年如何凄惨恶劣。现在，因为 Āryatewe 上座与Jñānasene 上座的努力，寺院已经被重建了。（现在）众僧情况很好，而且勤于善行。
尊者！关于 Puttisene 之前的四千（文）钱的负债，附有（我等的？）签署，那个给钱的人并不知道他（=Puttisene）（的情况）。（因为）那个人去远方。
现在，他（=Puttisene）已身负徭役，从 Śiṅku(n) 送信（出去）。
他（=债主）毫无尊敬之意，羞辱僧伽一次又一次。
尊者！Puttisene 是如何地（照）看这座寺院，他便也如何地夺走。
以上便是这件事的始末。（字面义为：“以上便是他的数额”）
他所拿走的东西，他必须（还）给我们。我们所欠他的，我们也将（还）给他。
尊者！对于他所夺走的东西，他不去想（它的价值）。它是算作违反的 ṣorye* 债务而从我这边被强行拿走的。
由于这个极端的情形，在 Śaṅke 的庇护......之下，他......对我们作出种种不友善的举动。
现在，请尊师稍微考虑一下我们的（解决之）道：这座寺院如何不再......土地，以使僧众不至于破散。元年十二月。
Saṅkästere 僧 Wiryamitre ¤
上座 Wäryasene ¤
上座Jñānasene ¤ Praskāre 僧 Mokṣacandre ¤
[上座]Āryatewe ¤
If he gives back to me what he has carried off, we [will] give back to him what we owe.
May the ācārya now think about an approach [lit. way] for us, so that the monastery will not (lose estate?)334 for a second time, and the proper situation of the community will not be terminated.

comments.comment: For aśari käṣṣi, cf. PK NS 296

I interpret the perlative as having the same function as in the accounts, namely that it indicates the total amount of money something is worth (in this case the amount paid to Puttisene) cf. PK DA M 507.7 a6 śakār käryāmtte śwersa.

Ching has śomo, but there is a stroke of ink above the 'mo', which I interpret as an anusvāra. This reading would give a better sense. It would be 'he (=Puttisene) did not take care of him (the creditor).'

The 'to me' (-ñ) indicates that whoever wrote this letter likely is in charge of the finances of the monastery, i.e. giving something to the monastery amounts to giving something to the author of the letter. However, -ñ could also be interpreted as a palatalized version of the 3rd person singular ending, conditioned by the following ce.
This is a constructio ad sensum: sāṅk is a singular, but the verb is in the plural.
I interpret -ñ here as a kind of dativus ethicus.
I take the two śka in the clauses to be coordinating.
perisa in the perlative preceded by a name in the genitive means 'as repayment for debt owed to X'.
This probably means that the debt was repayed not directly in coins/grain, but with a cheque.
maṣitär must be the medio-passive imperfect of yām-. The imperfect of mäsk- would be mäskītär.

In Khotanese, there is a document that attestes the term śiṃ kūṃ as an epithet the king Viśa Sambhava/李圣天 (P. 3510). argue that this term is a loan from Chinese 圣君 'sagely ruler'. Viśa Sambhava ruled in the 10th century, much later than our document. Could it be the case that 圣君 was already a common designation for a sovereign in Kucha much earlier than it was in Khotan? If so, Śiṅkun means 'the sagely sovereign', i.e. the Kuchean king. Could this term further have some connection with the Śaṅke official?
Ching considers this word to be a loan from Chinese 徭役 'corvée'.
points out that lkā- is a root very often used for kapyāri. This shows that Puttisene worked for the monastery.
That is, in an earlier letter.

It is not entirely clear what is meant here. Seemingly, through some legal technicality, the author of the letter was able to legally return ownership of the property Puttisene has stolen to the monastery. However, Puttisene has not physically returned the property, and is hiding behind the Śaṅke/Śaṅki (the title/name of an official whose main function is handling private debt disputes).
On account of the debt Puttisene has accrued in the name of the saṃgha.

The translation is a compromise between the solutions of different authors. I disagree with Ching that Puttisene is the debtor, because the phrase X-ntse perisa means "as repayment of debt to X", as already explained. Thus, Puttisene must be the creditor. There are some other details which I believe Ching gets wrong because of her assumption that Puttisene is the debtor, cf. in particular her translating a7-a8 puttisene ce sa/ṅkrām lkāṣi taiseṃ terisa cowai carka '(How) Puttisene had watched (over) this monastery, he (= the creditor?) seized (lit. 'robbed') in the same way.' There is no reason to assume a subject change between the two sentences. The focus of the letter is most definitely Puttisene, to whom the monastery owes debt and who harasses the saṅgha. It appears that this letter is only part of a larger correspondence, since it already assumes knowledge of who Puttisene is. It is probable that previous letters listed even more of Puttisene's embezzlement/thievery (this is probably what is meant by 'tuntse keś nauṣameṃ ste').

comments.comment: yśiñātsi looks like it is the same form as siñātsi/sijñātsi (PK DA M 507.35 a31, PK DA M 507.35 a47, PK DA M 507.38 a42). It is unclear what kind of sound is behind this variation, but it is obvious that it is not within the phonemic inventory of Tocharian. The same yś- onset is attested in yśuhkwā, suggesting that both of these names stem from the same language. argues that yśiñātsi is Chinese 十娘子 and siñātsi is 四娘子, 'the tenth daughter' and 'the fourth daughter', respectively.

comments.comment: sic!, although elsewhere nāśmi
The meaning of this word is unclear.

This word also occurs in . From the context, it appears to be some sort of grain. Strangely, outside of the secular corpus, the same word appears in the medical manuscripts (W 10, W 11, W 12) as mäśśakene. It is obviously a loan word, which could explain this kind of strange fluctuation in spelling.
The scribe has accidently written 'świ', but corrected himself.

line.tr: In the 4th regnal year. On the 28th day of the 4th (month), Saṅkatāse of Paśarki gave food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained: 2. The one, he ate himself. The other has been sold for 5 (coins).

On the 2nd day of the 5th (month), Erkañciśke gave food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained: 2. The one, Kercapiśke took (by giving its price) as 5 (coins). [The other, Raktaswiñi took (by giving its price) as 5 (coins).]
On the 8th day of the month, Yśiñātsi gave food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained: 2. The one, Yśiñātsi took. The other, Kuṃñcakke took. (Each has been sold) for five (coins. The sum is) 10.

On the 9th day of the month, Śaṅke of Ṣomoksa* gave food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained: 2. The one, Śilasome took (by giving its price) as 4 (coins). The other, Jñānaciwe took (by giving its price) as 3 (coins).

On the 11th day, Suklyike's people gave food. [The portions] (that) the Buddha obtained: 2. The one, Cinatyuti took (by giving its price) as 3 (coins). The other, Räktāśka took (by giving its price) as 3 (coins).
On the 15th day, [Koraña] gave food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained: 2. The one, Miki[n]e took (by giving its price) as 5 (coins). The other, Tātsi took (by giving its price) as 5 (coins).

On the 16th day, the women of Ṣomoksa* gave food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained: 2. The one, Kercapiśke took (by giving its price) as 4 (coins). The other, Śaṅke took (by giving its price) as 4 (coins).

On the 22nd day, the citizen Aṣtamikka*-women gave food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained: 2. They have been sold for coins (in sum): 10. The one, (Yarekke?) undertook (by giving its price) as 5 (coins).
Der Buddha erhielt zwei (2) Teile; je zu sechs wurden sie verkauft für zwölf (12) cāne's.
The Buddha received two (2) portions; at six each they were sold for twelve (12) cānes.
On the 23rd day, the citizen (and) the rural women gave food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained: 2, (each sold) for five (coins). They have been sold for coins (in sum): 10.
On the last day of the month, Wrau of Olyīṣkā gave food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained: 2, (each sold) for five (coins). They have been sold for coins (in sum): 10. [The month terminated.]

On the 15th day of the 6th (month), the people of Kalnīṅki gave food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained: 2. The one, Anandadewe took (by giving its price) as five (coins). The other, Wrau of Olyīśkā took (by giving its price) as [5] (coins).
On the 17th day, Korocciśka of [Olyīśkā] gave food. The portion (that) the Buddha obtained: one. Śiṅkācca took (it by giving its price) as 4 (coins).

On the 23rd day, Mpek Ccor gave food. [The portions (that) the Buddha obtained : 2. The one], [·u]ñ[ñ]ep took (by giving its price) as in 5 (coins). The other, Koñikka took (by giving its price) as 5 (coins).

On the 24th day, Tarmaiśye('s women??) gave food. [The portions (that) the Buddha obtained: 2. The one], Śiṅkācca took (by giving its price) as 5 (coins). The other, Raktaswiñi took (by giving its price) as 5 (coins).
On the last day of the month, Śiṅkācca gave food. The portion (that) the Buddha obtained: 1. Śiṅkācca took (it by giving its price) as 4 (coins). In the 7th month.
On the 1st day, Ṣṣirecca gave food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained: 2. The one, Sijñātsi took (by giving its price) as four (coins). The other, Tātsi took (by giving its price) as 4 (coins).

On the 7th day of the month, the portions (that) the Buddha obtained: (.... one) [has been sold for four coins. Another, Śaṅke the Wärweśakke took (by giving its price) as four (coins). The (rest) one, Citraswiñi of Saṅkika* took (by giving its price) as 4 (coins).

On the 15th day, Koraña gave food. The portions (that) the Buddhas [obtained: four]. One, Śirmāṃñca took (by giving its price) as four (coins). Another, Raktaswiñi [took (by giving its price) as four (coins)]. Another, Kä[nm]äṅk took (by giving its price) as four (coins). The (last) one, Jñānasene took (by giving its price) as three (coins).
On the 22nd day, Śilasome made sarañi. The portion (that) the Buddha obtained: 1. It has been sold for 3 (coins).

On the 23rd day, Ṣoṅk-seṃ gave food. The portion (that) the Buddhas obtained: 3. One, Yśiñātsi took (by giving its price) as four (coins). | Another, Puttikka took (by giving its price) as four (coins). | Another, Airkāca [took] (by giving its price) as four (coins). In total, (the price) in coins: 12. ///
Suklyike the Moko [took(?)] a portion ///
On the 27th day of the 10th (month), Cutte [gave food] ///
[4] (coins). The other, Caitike took (by giving its price) as 4 (coins).
On the 8th day of the 11th (month), Supriye of Teṅke gave food. The portion (that) the Buddha obtained: one. [I] gave the order to shave ... patsaśiś ... with (the cost of) this portion.
On the 15th day, Siñātsi [gave] food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained: [2]. They have been sold. (Each sold) for five (coins, The total price) in coins: 10.
On the 8th day of the 12th (month), Wrau of Olyīśkā gave food. The portion (that) the Buddha obtained: one. It has been sold for 2 (coins). ///
On the 19th day, Hkyauṅku gave food. ... [The Buddha] ... [has been sold] ... ///

translation.line: 二十二日，城里的八日筵的妇女们给了食物。佛陀获得贰份。[每份六(文）,] 卖出了，价钱拾贰10（文）。
二十三日，成立于乡村里的妇女们给了食物。佛陀获得贰份。每份五（文）卖出了，价钱拾（文）。
Der Buddha erhielt zwei (2) Teile; je zu sechs wurden sie verkauft für zwölf (12) cāne's.
In the regnal year four, (in the) fourth (month) on day twenty eight, Saṅkatāse of *Paśarki(ye?) donated food. The Buddha
received parts: two 2. One he ate himself, one was sold for five (coins) , as donation (?).
(In the) fifth (month) on day two, Erkañciśke donated food. The Buddha received parts: two 2. One
Kercapiśke took for five (coins) 5. One Raktaswiñi took for five (coins), as donation (?).
On day of the month eight, Yśiñātsi donated food. The Buddha received parts: two 2. One
Yśiñātsi took (he donated it), one Kuṃñcake took, each for five (coins), 10. (He donated it).
On day of the month nine, the Śaṅke of *ṣomokso donated food. The Buddha received parts: two 2.
One Śilasome took for four 4 (coins) (he donated it), one Jñānaciwe took for three (coins) (as a donation).
On day eleven, the Suklyiki donated food. The Buddha received parts: two 2. One Cinatyuti took
for three 3 (coins). One Raktāśka took for three 3 (coins). (They donated it)
On the day of the full moon, Koraña donated food. The Buddha received parts: two 2. One Mikine took
for five 5 (coins). One Tātsi took for five 5 (coins). (He donated it)
On day sixteen, the women of *Ṣomokso donated food. The Buddha received parts: two 2. One Kercapiśke
took for four 4 (coins) (he donated it). One the Śaṅke took for four 4 (coins). (He donated it)
On day twenty two, the urban *Aṣtami-women donated food. The Buddha received parts: two 2.
They were sold for coins: 10. One Yarekke took for five 5 (coins).
On day twenty three, the urban women in the village donated food. The Buddha received parts: two 2.
They were sold for five (coins) each, for ten 10 (coins).
On the last day of the month, the Wrau of Olyīśka donated food. The Buddha received parts: two 2. They were sold for two 2 (coins) each,
for ten 10 coins. The month has ended.
(In the) sixth (month), on the day of the full moon, the (people) of Kalnīṅki donated food. The Buddha received parts: two 2. One Anandadewe
took for five (coins), one the Wrau of Olyīśka took for five (coins). (He donated it).
On day seventeen, Koroñciśka of Olyīśka donated food. The Buddha received a part: One.
Śiṅkācca took it for four 4 coins. (She donated it)
On day twenty three, Bäg Čor donated food. The Buddha received parts: two 2. One ?-uññep took
for five 5 (coins). One Koñikka took for five 5 (coins). (She donated it).
On day twenty four, Tarmaiśyai donated food. The Buddha received parts: two 2. One Śiṅkācca (she donated it) took
for five 5 (coins), one Raktaswiñi took for five 5 (coins).
On the last day of the month, Śiṅkācca donated food. The Buddha received a part: one. Śiṅkācca took
it for four 4 (coins) (she donated it). In the seventh month
on the day of the new moon, Ṣirecca donated food. The Buddha received parts: two 2. One Sijñātsi took for four (coins) (he donated it).
One Tātsi took for four 4 (coins). (He donated it)
On day of the month seven, the Buddha received parts: ... One was sold for four (coins), One the Wärweśakke Śaṅke
took for four (coins) (he donated it). On Citraswiñi of Saṅkika took for four 4 (coins). (She donated it)
On the day of the full moon, Kauraña donated food. The Buddhas received parts: four. One Śirmāṃñca
took for four (coins, one Raktaswiñi took for four (coins, one Känmäṅk (?) took (he donated it) for four (coins).
One Jñānasene took for three (coins). (He donated it).
On day twenty two, Śilasome made sarañi. The Buddha received a part: one 1. It was sold for thee 3 (coins).
On day twenty three, Ṣoṅk-seṃ donated food. The Buddhas received parts: three 3.
One Yśiñātsi took for four (coins). One Puttikka took for four (coins). | One Turkāca took
for four (coins). In sum, for twelve coins 12.
The Moko Suklyike took a part ...
(In the) tenth (month), on day twenty seven, Cutte donated food ...
... for four 4 (coins). One Caitike took for four 4 (coins).
(In the) eleventh (month), on day of the month eight, Supriye of Teṅke donated food. The Buddha
received a part: one. I ordered to shave patsaśiś for this very part.
On the day of the full moon, Siñātsi donated food. The Buddha received parts: two 2. They were sold
for five (coins) each, for ten 10 coins.
(In the) last (month), on day of the month eight, the Wrau of Olyīśka donated food. The Buddha received a part:
one. It was sold for two 2 (coins).
On day nineteen, Hkyauṅku donated food. The Buddha...
... it was sold.
This is (the account?) of the stūpa.

comments.comment: From koroñciśka (as in PK DA M 507.38 a21), a diminutive of koroñci.

This name is probably derived from turkāne (SI 5874) by means of the Sogdian feminine suffix -c(a) (). The putative *turkāñca would then have undergone assimilation (like maṅkarāñcana in Pelliot Divers Bois Série C1 vs. maṅkarāccana in , or koroñciśka vs. korocciśka) and subsequent simplification of geminate -cc- (like ṣkace in PK DA M 507.38 a19 vs. ṣkacce in PK DA M 507.8 a1), ultimately yielding turkāca.

Note that the construction here is grammatically strange. One would expect either ṣe plaṅka or ṣeme pleksa. This kind of phenomenon where something that is expected to be in the casus rectus is in the casus obliquus is a very common phenomenon in the accounts.
The scribe first wrote 'lwi' but corrected himself.
Previously read as airkāca.
In this document, the phrase (tānesa) wasa is often inserted in smaller letters. This probably means that the members of the monastery paid the parts they bought back, cf. .

translation.line: [This] (is) the thing embezzled (lit. 'taken') by [Puttewante].
In the 24th regnal year, the Prefects of Samantatir were Akau (and) Meñiṃ.
... assigned ... to us/them: sixteen thousand. (These) were the coins [for (exempting our) service] (?).
[Puttewante] asked for all (the coins) ..., (but) he did not pay the dues/debt. [In the monastery ...]
(Sb.) paid the enclosed field of/to (sb.) (which was) due ... : [seven]
These seventy-six bolts of [kaum*]

In the 22nd regnal year, Candrawarme ... ... in total, he (= Puttewante) asked the due coins: six thousand. "Has Puttewante paid all? He has [not] paid the [debt/dues]." They (now) ask from Ś[w]esan*(?).
In the 23rd regnal year, in the 4th month. He (= Puttewante) asked for ten bolts of kaum* for Akau's attendance (?) in an army.
He said: "Akau asks for (it)." We borrowed (the ten bolts) from Wantiśke with interest (?). He (= Puttewante) did not give to Akau. For this reason, there have been twenty (bolts that we owe).
He took three bolts of kaum* as (the equivalent of) maṅkusäko*. (But) he did not buy maṅkusäko*. Neither did he pay (the levy by) the bolts of kaum*.
In the 23rd year, in the 8th month. Puttewante said: "Akau asks for one thousand coins."
[Korośkile] were ... thousand (coins). (Puttewante) [imposed on] Koroke*. //
... [Kercapiśke] ... from the Moko ... [to/of Puttewante]
... Puttewante [took] eight hundred coins concerning the enclosed field (in the domain?) of Mokṣa* ...
[untranslatable]
In the 23rd regnal year, in the 6th month, Puttewante came to me.

He said: "Akau (asks for) ten bolts of kaum* for his attendance (?) in the army. We acquired (them) from Wantiśke. But I have not given to Akau. Now I am scared. He will chase the ten bolts of kaum* after me. The horse to be delivered to Tukṣi* at the post station Olākwāṃ, I (will) perfectly prepare for us/you".

(Thus) I took (or borrowed?) one thousand two hundred coins from Korośkile of Tār*, as (the equivalent of) thirty-two (piculs of) grains." (Although) Puttewante gave the above coins to Capeś, he did not well prepare the horse.

In the 23rd regnal year, in the 4th month, Puttewante ordered us to buy a horse for giving (to the authorities) at the post station Olākwāṃ. We drove (by force) hither a horse (valued) at twenty bolts of kaum* from Wantiśke.
On that very day, Puttewante rode the horse down to a pond/spring, again he rode (it) back. There have been fourty (bolts). It was wounded. It died out.
Puttewante ... ... on this pretext/for this reason, there were fourty (bolts). ...
... Koroy ... a letter to the Great Commissioner ...
... to give fresh (grains), (sb.) [received/gained] thirty (piculs of) grains. [He gave wheat for ...].
Puttewante carried one grey mare away from Cipaiśe. Its sister was (assigned?) to Cipaiśe. He (= Puttewante) carried this one away (as well).
At (the cost of) the fresh grains of the 19th year, Puttewante made tanti for us. Yet he did not make it ready. In that while, he was on the way to Coṅkśi*, (so he was absent.)
Now, (to substitute for the failed tanti), Cipaiśe cannot complain about paying (of) grain (but seek to solve the trouble).
Puttewante gave that mare at Olākwāṃ in (the manner of?) ṣreṃ* (?). Puttawarme gave him one thousand coins. He has collected both mares (?).
Because of the dues/debt (assigned to?) the saṃgha, Koroy's paternal field was imposed for Ṣoṅkse*.On the pretext (about) Akau ... released(?) away...
He obtained three jars/vats of alcoholic beverage, (made of) tsäṅkana (?).
He obtained ... (coins) : fifteen thousand. ... dried(?)...
He sold ... for (the unit price of) ten (coins): five [hundreds?].
He obtained seeds of *eṅkara (?): chopped/husked(?), one picul.
In the 22nd regnal year, Puttewante embezzled Cinasene's own enclosed field, with the wheat produced (there).

Until now, it (i.e. the wheat?) is imposed (in Cinasene's name. There) is a jar/vat (and) a tsere of alcohol beverage (to be paid, and there) are six piculs of naked barley (to be paid). Akau is ... living ... he receives seeds of *eṅkara (?): ten piculs. The coins concerning Cinasene's enclosed field: six thousand.
In order to (pay the tax on) the enclosed farm, a land is imposed : six [piculs]. • ... of this enclosed farm ... Werpiśke gave .... Now, [in total]
(sb.) gave to Suklyike ... • ...
... [Puttewante used the enclosed farm] deprived from Cinasene, [quite arrogantly].
... (sth./sb.) has been [watched]. He says: "Twenty (piculs?) of wheat belong to Lyau[t]tu* is to be immediately carried by me from the prefecture."
He exempted the first (lit. 'one') brother nine bolts of kaum*. (This man, namely) Puttesene, (from) thirty-two bolts of kaum* (then) is working for Puttewante (as a deal).
He cannot fulfill the tax/corvée of the 4th year.
He (=Puttewante) deliberately(?) imposed on the second brother for Putteyāne: in (the amount of) twenty bolts of kaum*.
On the way to (the district) of Yśematka, Puttewante stole a donkey. ... of saṃgha (?) ... (sb.) gave ... •
All the ... of taxable (men/things) ...
... up to ... (sth.) is imposed. ... The thing ...
He imposed ... in the saṃgha ...: in two thousand five hundred (coins). • ... seven ... bolts of kaum* fell to (sb.). twenty bolts of kaum*
Now, in two places, Puttewante imposed on him. Puttewante ... the bolts of kaum*. •
In this year, Puttewante embezzled Ṣtakkale's enclosed field.
He imposed on (him sth.) to Āṃśi(?): for (the equivalent of) three thousand five hundred (coins).
[For] three [years], he imposed on Ṣtakkale's son in peṣkeṃn for Usūkore*: two thousand and five hundred (coins).
He [imposed] on Kṣemiśke*: ... [thousand] (coins).
In this year, he [imposed] on Erkañciśke
... for ppau.* •
[In (this) year], he [imposed on Sutane]
... coins. one thousand four hundred.
In (this) year, he sold Cinasene's daughter: ... ///
In (this) year, Yśematkaṣṣe (i.e. a man of Yśematka) gave to the saṃgha's five/ten bolts of kaum* to be brought. [Puttewante took (them)].
In (this) year, we obtained kaum* (produced?) in the estates (to be sent) to Teṅkiśke: eight bolts. Again, [Puttewante] took (them).
In (this) year, we obtained kaum* (produced?) in the estates at Paśārki*: five bolts. Puttewante took (them).
In the 23rd year, in the 10th month, Akau came to [the village/rural area] to accommodate (?) the Great Commissioner (on the way) to Ykāmeke*.
[Puttewante] made yośa* for him. A goat/sheep belong to the saṃgha ...
He gave alcoholic beverage ...: one picul, seven pecks. This alcoholic beverage ... [naked barley] .... He even took millet l. ...: seven piculs, five pecks.
We bought yakso* in Olākwāṃ: five pecks, at (a cost of) one picul and five pecks of millet l.. It is ālttsettstsa (?) to give/pay.
Puttewante gave naked barley to Akau for a yośa*: one peck. He even took five pecks of millet l. belonging to the saṃgha.
And this Puttewante ... from Akau ... let go the saṃgha's (property?) as the matter of tom pari (?).
In total, the excessive levy that has been taken/embezzled by Puttewante: ...
Bolts of kaum*: one hundred and ninty-eight ... (Given the price per bolt as three hundred coins, the equivalent amount of coins was: fifty-nine thousand) for hundred. •
Coins were: ...

Grain is: six hundred eighty-one piculs, five pecks. (Given) the price (per peck as) [five] (coins, the equivalent amount of) coins was: thirty-four thousand and seventy-five. (i.e. 5 x 6815 = 34075).

Alcoholic beverage was: five jars/vats (and) a tsere. He sold one thousand five hundred (coins per jar/vat). In total, the (equivalent amount of) coins was: eight thousands two hundred and fifty. (5.5 x 1500 = 8250)
[To sum up], the bolts of kaum*, the coins, the grain, the alcoholic beverage, ...: one hundred eleven [thousand] ...
To Kuleṅkar-Akau, the Vice Commissioner and Great General: The kapyāres of Samantatir, led by Suklyike, address (to you) very deferentially.
Oh lord! The (things that) Puttewante has done lawlessly [to us], or the things that have been taken (by him), they have been written above. • The account is (given) above.
(Previously) [I have given] this indictment (lit. 'thing, affair'). If the Minister had made/done (something), there would have been much progress (of it).
Similar to us, a servant/slave nearby ... He mistreated ... more badly than dogs.
Now, ... he made our parts ... : at Arnassi*, in five karpoñña* (?). He [has dispatched] twenty-eight men, together with a woman and a boy. •
He said: " ... I do (sth.) ... for the monastery. ...
At (the cost/value of) sixteen (?) thousand (coins), (delivered) to hand ...
Thus the tax/levy will fall (to us). ...
He [imposed] ... seven persons ...
... the field cannot be cultivated by us/them neither. • He controlled himself the goat/sheep (in) pasture/pen (?).
And this litigation ... [the] ... many things. It has been taken (by Puttewante). We, in whatever circumstance, ... this [debt] ... , rather than prepare the tax/levy. •
Now, we all together have come here. Therefore this is our request: the things that Puttewante has taken/embezzled ... he compensates (?) our ... .
What Akau should have obtained, [we will ... ] ... that. • What Akau (should not obtain) ...
[He imposed] deliberately(?) on two brothers ...
(to us/them). • The enclosed field ... on the pretext of (payment/levy) to Akau, ... ... (that) he obtained, he should return to us.
But what has been imposed (in the form of) enclosed fields, we should obtain them (by a decree of release?). •
Therefore, in order to settle the village/rural area (of/and) the monastery, ... I will settle ... the Teṃttsäwe village/area ... , ...
All the estate (that) Puttewante has ... ... are to/of us.
Therefore, we will not leave ... either. •
... of/to/by Puttewante ...

Laraiyśe*'s finger-measure.

[此为 Puttweante] 取人财物事。
二十四年，Samantatir 的地方长官们是 Akau 与 Meñiṃ ......。
...... 向我们／他们征派一万六千（文）。（这些是）为了（充抵？）我们／他们差役的钱。
[Puttewante] 要求了...... 全部，却没有交税。
二十三年（741？）六月，Puttewante 来我这里
他说：”Akau 要求十匹绢帛，因为他在军中要做招待（？）。我们从 Wantiśke 边拿到了，但我没有交给 Akau。现在我怕他会为了那十匹绢帛来追缉我。（所以，）要递交给乌骆馆的 Tukṣi* 的一匹马，为了你们／我们，我会好好准备。“
（于是）我从 Tār* 的 Korośkile 处以三十二（石）粮食（换？）取一千两百（文）钱。虽然 Puttewante （将钱）交给 Capeś，却没把马准备好。......[以下为另一人证词]
二十三年四月，Puttewante 要求我们买匹马，要交给乌骆馆的。我们用二十匹绢帛从 Wantiśke 身边带走一匹马。
当天 Puttewante 骑这匹马到池塘／泉水边，又骑它回来。他受伤然后死了。
......因为这个缘故，四十（匹）...... Puttewante ...... [以下可能为另一人证词]
Puttewante 拉走一匹青色草马。它的姐妹是要给 Cipaiśe 的，他也把它拉走。
（而）Puttewante 应该为我们作 tanti, 要用（某王）十九年的新收粮食（来作）。但他毫无准备。当时他正要去 Coṅkśi* 的路上（，所以他不在）。
现在 Cipaiśe 不能为交粮一事抱怨。
至于那匹草马，Puttewante 以 ṣreṃ* 的方式给了乌骆馆。Puttewarme 给他一千（文）钱，于是两匹草马都被征走了。
我获得了用三个翁（装盛）的酒：[青]
有一 lwaṅke 一 tsere 的酒（要缴）；有六石青（要缴）。
Puttewante 故意向三兄弟征课。他从兄弟其中一人夺走九匹 kaum* 三十二匹 kaum*。（此人，即）Puttisene, 一直为 Puttewante 工作，（以至于）没有去作（某王）第四年的课役。他又故意让兄弟里的另一人为了 Putteyāne 受课（或：”去 Putteyāne 那儿缴税“？）：二十匹 kaum*。
二十三年十月，Akau 来到乡下迎接（？）前往 Ykāmeke*的大使。[Puttewante] 为他作了 yośa*。属于僧伽的一头羊......
他给了酒：一石七斗。这酒......青课......他甚至拿了 lyekśiye：七石无斗。
总计 Puttewante 迄今所取物事：......
kaum*: 一百九十八（个）......
谷麦为六百八十一石五斗。价格（每斗）五（文，值）钱三万四千七[百]十五[文]。
酒为五 lwāṅke（又）一 tsere。（每 lwāṅke）售一千五百（文），共（值）钱八千二百五十（文）。
这些 kaum*、钱、谷麦、酒以钱【合】计
（十）一万一[千]
致副使大将军 Kᵤleṅkar-Akaumś：Samantatir 之诸净人，以 Suklyike 为[首]（向您）致敬。
大人！Puttewante 所作的非法行为，以及被（他）夺取的物事，这......都写在上面。数量如上。
（以前）[我已经投] 书。要是（那时候）大臣已经有所处置，这件事情理当会有不少进展。

comments.comment: It is strange that skāyā- seems to be used with a direct object here, something that is attested nowhere else. Usually skāyā- takes the infinitive or in rare cases mäkte. I translate the word here as 'seek'.
[man]te or [mak]te.
This probably is not a genitive in -i but a simple scribal error for saṅkayśintse.
This line could suggest that the translation of okoṣe śātre as 'ripened grain' might be wrong.
Might this be a mistake for kanti?
Considering ṣaime a mistake for ṣeme, cf. .
Interpreting eñcilmaṣes as genitive plural of *eñcilmaṣe, this maybe being a late form of *eñcilänmaṣṣe, i.e. the people on whom Puttewante eñcil tesa.
Cf. SI 5872 tseñai keṃ armañik, .
For āś yāmtsi, cf. Sanskrit murdhnā kṛ-
Assuming yamastar = yamastär.

This means that he took control of e.g. Cinasene. This interpretation makes sense, since Puttewante sold Cinasene's daughter, meaning he certainly exerts control on the rightful owner of the field itself.
śallau = śalnaᵤ
For atameṃ = 'away', cf. .

A general peculiarity of PK DA M 507.37 is a bow-shaped thick stroke above some akṣaras, the meaning of which is uncertain. It appears above ko ra keṃ in 14, ṣeṃ pu in 16, yi ltse in 20, ya ltse in 31 and na tā in 40. It does not occur in PK DA M 507.36, only in 37.
There's a +-sign above the 'ṣu'.
There's a +-sign above the 'rya'.
There's a +-sign above the 'i'.
The last few signs in guillemets are actually written in small letters between line 23 and 24. They were added later.
The 'pi' of pi śKA tstsa was used to write over a 're'. It seems the scribe first intended to write *plyeṅksare, but corrected himself by overwriting the 're'.
The last few akṣaras are actually written between line 40 and 41. There is a +-sign above 'ṣa' in e ṅka ra ṣa na.

line.tr: In the 5th regnal year of the king Nāśmi, (a year of) [sheep/goat]. /// /// obtained.
On the 28th day of the 4th (month), Saṅkatāse of Paśarki gave food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained: 2. One has been sold for 5 (coins), the other he ate himself.
Der Buddha erhielt zwei (2) Teile; ein [Teil] wurde für fünf (5) verkauft.
The Buddha received two (2) portions; one [portion] was sold for five (5).
On the 2nd day of the 5th (month), Erkañciśke [gave food. The portions (that) the Buddha] obtained : 2. The one, Kercapiśke took (by giving its price) as 5 (coins). [The other] ///
On the 8th day of the month, Yśiñātsi [gave food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained : 2.] They have been sold, each for five (coins. The total:) 10.

On the 9th day of the month, Śaṅke of Ṣomoksa* [gave] food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained : 2. One has been sold for 4 (coins). The other Jñānaciwe the novice took (by giving its price) as 4 (coins).
On the 11th day, [Suklyike's people] gave food. [The portions (that) the Buddha obtained : 2. They have been sold, each for three (coins)]. (The total:) 6 (coins).
On the 15th day, Koraña gave food. ... [the Buddha] ... (by giving its price) as [5] (coins). The other, Miki[n]e took (by giving its price) as 5 (coins).
On the 16th day, the women of Ṣomoksa* gave food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained : 2. They have been sold, each for four (coins). The total in coins: 8.
On the 23rd day, the citizen (and) the rural (women gave food. The portions that the Buddha) [obtained]: 2. They have been sold, each for five (coins). The total in coins : 10.
On the 24th day, the citizen Aṣtamikka*-women [gave] food. The portions (that) the Buddha obtained : 2. They have been sold, each for five (coins). The total in coins : 10.
On the last day of the month, Wrau of Olyīṣkā [gave food]. /// /// [2]. They have been sold, each for four (coins. The total in coins:) 10.

On the 15th day of the 6th (month), the people of Laikār* gave food. [The portions (that) the Buddha obtained:] (2.) One has been sold for five (coins). The other, the novice Jñānaciwe took (by giving its price) as 5 (coins).
On the 17th day, Koroñciśka of Olyīśkā (gave) food. The portion (that) the Buddha obtained : one. It has been sold for 4 (coins).
On the 23rd day, Mpek Ccor [gave] food. [The portions (that) the Buddha obtained:] (2. One) [has been sold] for five (coins). The other, Ṅkitsai took (by giving its price) as 5 (coins).

On the 24th day, Tarmaiśye gave food. The portions (that) [the Buddha obtained]: 2. The one, Śiṅkācca took (by giving its price) as five (coins). [The other, Raktaswiñi] (took by giving its price as) [5] (coins).
On the last day of the month, Śiṅkācca [gave food]. /// /// (one). [Śiṅkācca took] (by giving its price) as 4 (coins).
On the 1st day, Ṣirecca gave food. [The portions] (that the Buddha) obtained: 2. They have been sold, each for four (coins). The total in coins: [8].
On the 7th day of the month, the portions (that) the Buddha (obtained: 3) [They have been sold, each for four coins. The total] in coins: 12.

On the 15th day, Koraña gave food. [The portions (that) the Buddha] obtained: 3. One has been sold for four (coins). Another, Śirmāñca [took] (by giving its price) as four coins. The rest one), [Raktaswiñi took] (by giving its price) as four (coins).
On the 22nd day, Śilasome [made] sarañi. [The portion] (that the Buddha) obtained: one. It has been sold for 3 (coins).

On the 23rd day, Ṣoṅkseṃ [gave food]. The portion (that) [the Buddhas obtained]: 3. One has been sold for 4 (coins). Another, Puttikka took (by giving its price) as 4 coins. (The rest one) [Airkāca] took (by giving its price) as 4 (coins).
On the 27th day of the 10th (month), Cutte gave food /// /// [4] (coins). The other, Caitike took (by giving its price) as 4 (coins). /// /// ...
On the 8th day of the 11th (month), [Supriye gave] (food). The portion (that) the Buddha obtained: one. [I] gave the order to shave ... large/great patsaśiś.
On the 15th day, Siñātsi [gave] food. (The portions that the Buddha) [obtained: 2. They have been sold], each for five (coins). The total in coins: 10.
On the 8th day of the 12th [month, Wrau] of Olyīśkā [gave food]. The portion (that) the Buddha obtained: one. It has been sold for 2 (coins).
On the 19th day, Kyauṅku gave food. (The portions that the Buddha obtained):[2]. The one has been sold for 4 (coins). [The other] has been sold for 3 (coins).
Accordingly, the coins as the income [are] /// ///
On the 20th day of the 4th (month), I bought fragrance ... /// /// has seen.
For the full moon of the 5th (month), [I bought] fragrance /// /// [Kercapiśke has seen]. [SIGNUM]
On the 9th day of the 6th month, (I bought) keklyenta. /// /// [Jñānasene] has seen.
On the 11th day, Kercapiśke (left in order to) mill wheat. [For paying the fee], I gave him the [stūpas'] coins: 25. [Kercapiśke]'s finger-measure. [SIGNUM]
On the 21st day, Kercapiśke (left in order to mill) [wheat]. /// /// ... I gave him the coins to pay the fee (distributed to ?) the stūpa/Buddha: 2[7]. (Kercapiśke's) [finger-measure]. [SIGNUM]
The 7th month. (On) the 6th day of the month, ... [fragrance] ... for 2 (coins). [C]i- /// /// [finger-measure]
For prawarik*, [I bought] ... for the lamp to/of the Buddhas: two and a half pints, for 10 (coins). [Kercapiśke] (has seen. Finger-measure.) [SIGNUM]
On the [23rd] day of the 8th (month), [I bought] fragrance for [4/5] (coins). [Kercapiśke] (has seen). This (is his) finger-measure. [SIGNUM]
On the 21st day of the 9th (month), ... [Anandadewe] /// /// ... to give 50 (coins). [Jñānarakṣite] (has recognized).
On the 13th day of the 10th (month), [I bought] fragrance /// /// [has seen. This (is his) finger-measure].
On the 17th day of (the month), I bought kekleynta for three (coins). /// /// (has seen. This is his) finger-measure. [SIGNUM]
For the full moon of the 11th (month, I bought) fragrance /// /// [Pu] /// /// (has seen. This is his/her) finger-measure.
On the 13th day of the 12th (month), I gave to [Indrawarme] (coins): [3], in order to (pay) the fee of milling. [Indrawarme's Finger-measure.]

Lines a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 a7 a8 a9 a10 a11 a12 a13 a14 a15 a16 a17 a18 a19 a20 a21 a22 a23 a24 a25 a26 a27 a28 a29 a30 a31 a32 a33 a34 a35 a36 a37 a38 a39 a40 a41 a42 a43 a44 a45 a46 a47 are a chronological record of incomes of the monastery, lines a49 a50 a51 a52 a53 a54 a55 a56 a57 a58 a59 a60 a61 a62 a63 a64 a65 a66 a67 a68 a69 are a record of expenses; the ms. is a revised copy of PK DA M 507.35 and PK DA M 507.42 and .40; see .

The word māk is difficult to explain. It appears to be the negation mā + the particle -k. It corresponds to tānesa (wasa) in PK DA M 507.35, thus it might be a means of recording that someone hasn't given his portion back to the saṅgha.

comments.comment: meñi is rather strange here. One would expect meñ.
If not tauṣalas, this word could be related to nauṣ, but its derivation is obscure.
Nearly illegible due to multiple corrections; reads śwārka, reads śāk-ṣe.

ce could also be a relative pronoun, but since the context is obscure, it is difficult to decide. śawośaṃ is a late form of śawośañ, which explains as being derived from a verbal noun *śāwo + the verb śawā-, saying that it has 'negative' connotations. However, there does not seem to be any such connotation in this case. Interestingly, śawośaṃ takes ce śātre as its direct object. This is similar to Vedic RV 1.12.1C tā somaṃ somapātamā 'These two are the best Soma-drinkers (of) Soma.' ().

The krāktsa appears to be some kind of functionary within the monastery, who among other things is in charge of milling (), cf. PK DA M 507.41 a8. This doesn't necessarily mean that krāktsa must be an exact equivalent of the waltsaucca of the Berlin collection.
These two akṣaras are a complete mess. 'śwā rka' is just the closest thing resembling them.
Interestingly, the verso side is written in a different ductus than the recto side. The 'r's look completely different and more resemble the 'r's of the accounts in the Berlin collection.

comments.comment: This is an important passage. If it weren't for it, we would not be able to say much about the functions the tsañi fulfills. Since we now know Kercapiśke, who leaves his finger-measure in the documents of PK DA M 507 constantly, was a Tsañi we can say with certainty that the Tsañi is a layman who works for the monastery and fulfills administrative functions which often overlap with those of a regular kapyāre, often times taking commodities into and from the monastery himself (cf. PK DA M 507.20 a7, PK DA M 507.34 a26). Even more interestingly, if is correct in connecting 处半白吉招失鸡 in PK DA M 507.31 with Kercapiśke, then it is very likely that TB tsañi is the equivalent of Chinese 处半, for which cf. , a document written in TA which has a form [co]ppāṃ..
Ching wrongly transliterates sa ñi here, but we most definitely have a shoddily written tsa, although the upper part is a bit smushed together.
The 'r' is very clearly visible, the 'c' is slightly obscured by ink from the verso, but it is also visible. Not with Ching 'cā'.
The 'KA' here looks very close to the 'KA' in the lettres commerciales.
The two dots for the 'wä' very much look rather peculiar. They look like bowls.

Recto and verso are once again written in a different ductus. The recto has 'r's in an L-shape, the 'r's on the verso are more like those in Berlin. Also, the two dots marking the weak vowel 'ä' are different.

line.tr: On the 20th day of the 4th (month), I bought fragrance for 3 (coins) ... ///
For the Full moon (= the 15th day) in the 5th (month), I bought fragrance .... [Kercapiśke has seen].
On the 9th day of the 6th month, (I bought) keklyenta ... [Jñānasene has seen].
On the 11th day, Kercapiśke (left in order to) [mill] wheat. (For paying the fee, I gave him the coins of the stūpa/Buddha: 25.
On the 21st day, (Kercapiśke) left in order to mill (wheat). I gave him stūpas' coins: 2[7].
(On the 6th day of the 7th month), [I bought] (fragrance) for 2 (coins).
For pravarik*, (I bought oil/ghee) for the lamp to the Buddhas: (two) pints, for 12 (coins).
On the [23rd] day of the 8th (month, I bought fragrance) for (five coins). Kercapiśke has seen.
On the 13th day of the 10th (month, I bought) fragrance for [3] coins. Sutane has seen.
For the full moon of the 11th (month, I bought) fragrance ... [Laraiyśe] has seen.
On the 21st day of the 9th (month), [I gave] ... (to the) [musicians] ... [50] (coins).
[On the 13th day] of the 12th (month), I gave coins to Indrawarme: [3].

translation.line: 九月二十一日，[我给了]乐工......[伍拾]（文）。
(In the) tenth (month) on day twenty, I bought perfume for three 3 (coins). Sutane saw it.
(In the) fifth (month), I bought perfume for the full moon ... Kercapiśke saw it.
(In the) tenth (month), on day of the month nine, I bought kekleynta... Jñānasene saw it.
On day eleven, Kercapiśke went to grind. To pay the price, I gave him coins belonging to the stūpa:
twenty five 25. On day twenty one, Kercapiśke went to grind wheat.
I gave coins belonging to the stūpa: twenty seven 27. (In the) seventh (month) on day six, I bought perfume for two 2 (coins).
For Pravāraṇā, I bought oil for the lamp of the Buddhas: two pints for
twelve 12 (coins). (In the) eighth (month), on day twenty three, I bought perfume for five 5 (coins). Kercapiśke
saw it. (In the) tenth (month) on day thirteen, I bought perfume for three 3 (coins). Sutane saw it.
(In the) eleventh (month), I bought perfume for the full moon...
...saw it. | (In the) ninth (month), on day twenty one I gave ... to the musicians: fifty 50.
(In the) final (month), on day thirteen, I gave coins to Indrawarme: three 3.
